channel.title: Data Science with R and Python
channel.description: Recent content on Data Science with R and Python

item.title: The two most important functions for data visualisation in R
item.description: In my opinion, the two most important functions for data visualisation are Par and Pairs functions. Par Function The first function is par function with mfrow parameter. The par(mfrow=c(rows,columns)) allows us to plot multiple plots on the same page or window. Here is an example with IRIS dataset. First, loading and inspecting the dataset #import libraries library(datasets) #loading iris dataset data(iris) #The first six rows with the four columns head(iris) ## Sepal.

item.title: Inner Join, Outter Join, Left Join, Right Join, Row Bind, Column Bind in R
item.description: The merge operations is well explained in Pandas documentation for Python but I could not find any documentation that is as good for R. Hence, I am writing this blog :) Letâ€™s say we have these two data frames #import libraries library('data.table') df1<-data.frame(Country=c('US','UK',"New Zealand"),Rank =c(1,2,3)) df2<-data.frame(Country=c('US','UK',"New Zealand"),Population =c(300,80,4)) df1 ## Country Rank ## 1 US 1 ## 2 UK 2 ## 3 New Zealand 3 df2 ## Country Population ## 1 US 300 ## 2 UK 80 ## 3 New Zealand 4 Before jumping to merging these two data frames, we can consider adding one data frame to another.

item.title: About
item.description: I am passionate about data and quantitative analysis. I write about data cleansing, manipulation and analysis using R and Python programming languages. I write to learn, understand and give back to the community.
